# Vacation Policy

All full-time employees are entitled to 20 days of paid vacation per year. Vacation days accrue monthly at a rate of 1.67 days per month. Unused vacation days can be carried over to the next year, up to a maximum of 5 days. Employees must submit vacation requests at least 2 weeks in advance for approval by their manager. During peak business periods (Q4), vacation requests may be limited.

# Remote Work Policy

Employees may work remotely up to 3 days per week with manager approval. Remote work arrangements must be documented and reviewed quarterly. All remote workers must maintain a dedicated workspace, reliable internet connection, and be available during core hours (10 AM - 3 PM local time). Equipment allowances of up to $500 are available for home office setup.

# Code Review Guidelines

All code changes require at least one approval before merging. Reviewers should check for: code correctness, test coverage (minimum 80%), adherence to style guides, and documentation updates. Reviews should be completed within 24 business hours. Use conventional comments: 'nit' for minor suggestions, 'blocking' for required changes.

# Incident Response Procedure

Severity 1 (Critical): Production down, customer impact. Response within 15 minutes. Page on-call engineer immediately.
Severity 2 (High): Major feature degraded. Response within 1 hour.
Severity 3 (Medium): Minor feature issues. Response within 4 hours.
Severity 4 (Low): No customer impact. Response within 24 hours.

All incidents require a post-mortem within 5 business days.

# First Week Checklist

Day 1: Complete HR paperwork, set up laptop, meet your manager and team.
Day 2: Complete security training, set up development environment.
Day 3: Review team documentation, shadow a team member.
Day 4: Pick up a small starter task, attend team standup.
Day 5: Complete first code review, 1:1 with manager.

Your buddy will be assigned to help you during your first month.

# Data Handling Policy

Customer data must be encrypted at rest and in transit. PII (Personally Identifiable Information) requires additional protections: access logging, retention limits (max 2 years), and deletion upon customer request. Never log PII in application logs. All data access must follow the principle of least privilege. Regular audits are conducted quarterly.
